intro: Corydalis moorcroftiana, commonly known as the Tibetan Corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Fumariaceae and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and clusters of small, delicate flowers. The flowers typically bloom in shades of pink, purple, or white, and are borne on long, slender pedicels. The plant has lance-shaped leaves that are often hairy and grow along the stem. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky soils.
